abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile focuses on
            community management in Nepal which rekindled schooling.
            Nepal is a small, landlocked but relatively populous country
            in South Asia, with about 28 million people. By the early
            1950s the country had only twenty two high schools, of which
            twenty were community built, financed and managed. In 1972,
            however, the government took over more than 8,000 schools.
            But 30 years of neglect had taken a heavy toll. Literacy
            rates were 52 percent, compared to 58 percent in South Asia
            and 61 percent among low-income countries around the world.
            The International Development Association financed Community
            School Support Project was launched in 2003 to help reform
            the defunct public school system. Net primary enrollment
            rose from 84 percent in 2003 to 92 percent in 2008. Gender
            parity improved from 83 percent to 98 percent during the
            same period. More than 8,600 schools transferred back to
            community management for the transition in education sector.
